text: Patient: Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: What is the effects of a seizure? Doctor: Well a seizure is exactly what you see on TV you know when your brain is too hyperactive and you’re kind of going like this and you can’t control it. Patient: Okay so what do we do? And the reason why… Doctor: If that happens she’s calling nine one one, but it’s a percent chance less than that. Okay. Patient: Okay then let me ask you this here doc. Let me ask you this here. If I had a seizure Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: right now Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and we ain’t in the hospital. Doctor: Okay. Patient: What would you do to accommodate me with the seizure other than dialing nine one one?

text: Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Or - Doctor: There are six drugs that have been approved by the FDA right now specifically for hormone-resistant prostate cancer. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Two of those six are chemos. One is immunotherapy, one is a bone-targeted therapy for bone metastases and two are pills. So there are six drugs in addition to the conventional, old-fashioned hormone therapy that we only use if the cancer becomes hormone-resistant. Healthcare Professional: And there are other ones in development right now. Doctor: And there are many other ones in development, which I explained. Family Member: So are we not working towards cure are we working towards remission? Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Absolutely. And again, some of these remissions are very long-lasting. Healthcare Professional: And there are people who go on hormone therapy and don’t need a second-line hormone. Like they’re in remission for fifteen years. Now he’s telling you an average but we see people who don’t need another therapy you know for many, many years. So you know it’s, you know again, I mean we don’t worry about fall –

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - I need to know about it right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that- Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: are possible side effects of these medications. Family Member: Okay. text: Family Member: Why are they not approving the chemo? Doctor: I have no clue. They don’t have to give a reason remember? They just say denied so then we’re like we don’t understand and then you play the round robin, you know talk to that person, talk to that person, at some point it’s gonna have to be talk to the Medical Director and I’m gonna be like this ain’t complicated. I would image it has probably a lot to do with you were on a trial and now you’re not and they’re behind right. So we’re moving at real time speed… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And stuff that they have is like always behind so you know there isn’t a – there isn’t a visit right now until right now for us to say well you’re done with that study, you’re now getting Taxotere just like a regular non-study patient and I’m sure they haven’t processes that in their head. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they go everything by notes. So everything for you has been on, on, on – oh we’re now going to get radiation, Patient: Okay. Doctor: so they don’t have a way to read and say that what I’m saying correct. Because if it’s not in a document then it isn’t so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that’s a struggle for us, but I have a feeling that’s what it is. But hey this may be a blessing in disguise. You’ve got the fourth coming up, you might as well just enjoy it. We will reschedule next week. I’ll scream at a bunch of more people because what else do I have to do. Doctor: And then by then hopefully the shot will have worked out. Patient: Okay

text: Patient: So you don’t want me to take Xtandi at all anymore? Healthcare Professional: No, stop it. Family Member: Can we donate it to somebody that needs it? Healthcare Professional: Yeah, bring it back in. Doctor: Bring it back to us and we’ll make sure it gets recycled to the next person, absolutely. Family Member: To the next person who needs it. Doctor: And we have a process to do that. Family Member: Somebody that needs it because I know how expensive it is. Doctor: Yes, and we appreciate that. Family Member: Yeah, we’ll bring it back. Doctor: Okay, sounds like a plan. Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
